Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Virtual Music helper, next-generation educational social platform for conservatory music practice and performance empowered by AI and AR
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project focuses on development of a prototype for a Virtual Music Helper (VMH) for children. Research confirms that music and music learning enhances intelligence, learning and IQ specially in kids. Even children with attention deficit/ hyperactivity disorder benefit from listening to music beforehand in mathematics tests. Children who learn or practice music have shown better results in STEM subjects. However, studies also suggest children opt out of music class based on false belief that they lack musical ability and many kids often find the music practice non-engaging, and boring eventually losing interest and quitting. Parents find it challenging to entice the kids to sit down and practice or they cannot help their kids because either they don?t have time or are not music savvy themselves to help them. The virtual music helper can read the kids? music homework, guide them through the exercise and provide immediate correction. This helper is not to replace teachers, but help the parents at home and encourage kids to practice more. In broader terms this project may spur significant research in finding effective methods for tutoring kids in subjects other than music such as math or language, or for kids with special needs.


This SBIR Phase I project proposes a Virtual Music Helper (VMH) that is empowered by Artificial Intelligence and Augmented Reality for kids. VMH is a 3D mobile-virtual-human (avatar) that can be personalized for each kid and conduct live dialog with kids both from visual and behavioral perspectives. VHM offers smart content for teachers about each student's progress and weak points. The technical challenges this project will address is the detection and correction of mistakes kids make including polyphonic pitch detection from acoustic instrument, conversion of note sheets to machine readable music format with high accuracy and speed, empowering the avatar with decision making algorithms to provide proper correction and feedback verbally and visually. This platform is also intended to support multiple popular instruments and multiple languages.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research confirms that music and music learning enhances learning and IQ specially in kids, including enhancing Reading and literacy skills, Spatial-temporal reasoning, Mathematical abilities. However, studies also suggest children opt out of music based on false belief they lack ability, or many kids often find the music practice non-engaging and hard and eventually lose interest and quit. The statistics show that about %64 of kids in USA get music education, but about %50 of them will drop out of music within 1 or 2 years thinking there are not talented enough, or music is hard to learn. Parents find it challenging to entice the kids to sit down and practice. In many cases, parents cannot help the kids because either they don’t have time or are not music savvy themselves to help them. All these result in kids dropping out of music, or thinking they are not talented enough in this space.

 

Our research started with a social mission that every kid regardless of their social economical background is talented, and deserves a well-balanced education that include ART specially music. The benefits of music education as mentioned above is well known. If we could find a way to inspire, and encourage the kids to practice, play music more and effectively at home specially without the help from the parents, we could be successful in keeping the kids in music for longer period of time. Eventually, this may even inspire them to pursue a career in ART. Additionally, a good music education could also benefit students later on in life, for instance, many students receive scholarship via music programs offered at universities or colleges.

 

The initial scope of our research project was to address the aforementioned problem “to research, design and test the next generation “Virtual Music Helper” (VMH) empowered by Artificial Intelligence and Augmented Reality for kids to inspire them to create, practice and perform music in an engaging and collaborative way specially without parents helps at home or as a teaching tool for teachers at school or music schools and studio”.

 

As part of this research project, we decided to apply “situated learning” theory which was a successful learning methodology in other subjects, and apply it to music learning. In situated learning, the users are given a goal and a social environment to collaborate and achieve that goal. Essentially in our research, we wanted to give kids small goals such as learning a few measures, and a social environment to create, practice and perform together in an engaging and collaborative manner, and ultimately, share their music album and videos with their private collaboration groups being family, music studio, classroom, virtual classroom (show their talent). We prototyped a virtual music helper that included the four technical research areas successfully. We also tested the prototype with multiple schools, music schools and individual users (more than 500 users). The technical areas for research included:

 

1-    3D Virtual Avatar helper to provide live feedback and encouragement throughout the practice.

2-    Polyphonic pitch detection algorithms to be able to detect live multi-notes and chord mistakes.

3-    Enhanced and accurate OMR technology to be able to read music homework and digitize it to a format that we can use to detect the mistakes.

4-     Augmented Reality Social musical environment to create, practice and perform in a collaborative manner, and share the music creation (albums and video) with friends, classroom, virtual classrooms or collaboration groups.

 

We were able to complete customer discovery phase, prototype and test the product idea with music schools and schools as part of phase I. We identified the areas of improvements and adjustment required for commercialization phase (phase II).  We believe, our product will have huge social and technological impact in music education while making it affordable and accessible to all groups. We will be able to bring music education into every home, or remote area and make it affordable for every child across the globe to be able to create, practice and perform music in a safe, collaborative and affordable environment whether they are in a classroom, virtual classroom, comfort of their home or any geographical location.

 

Our goal is to allow every kid or adult (specially seniors) regardless of their social economical background, or health-profile to be able to join a collaboration group to learn, create, practice and perform music it together. Imagine a world that normal people (not just musician) can make and play music together. Everyone is Talented!
